entry.title: Retable of the Virgin of Montserrat (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Retable of the Virgin of Montserrat (pictured) was commissioned by a merchant, perhaps as a sign of gratitude for his safe return from a shipwrecked journey from Savona to Valencia?

entry.title: Jim Rich (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Jim Rich served as editor-in-chief of the Daily News twice?

entry.title: Hirbemerdon Tepe (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the site of Hirbemerdon Tepe was initially inhabited in the Chalcolithic and continued to be populated until the Ottoman Empire?

entry.title: Flathead Lake Biological Station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Flathead Lake Biological Station can detect invasive aquatic species in real-time using eDNA technology?

entry.title: Wantage Code (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Wantage Code, a record of laws promulgated by the English king Æthelred the Unready and his councillors around 997, may provide the earliest description of a jury of presentment?

entry.title: North Koreans in Kamchatka (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in the Russian Far East, there is a population of North Koreans in Kamchatka that now aligns itself with South Korea?

entry.title: Tom Rutherford (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that New Zealand politician Tom Rutherford is a firefighter and hockey umpire?

entry.title: Davy's on the Road Again (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that later pressings of the soundtrack of the soft porn film The Stud replaced Manfred Mann's Earth Band's "Davy's on the Road Again" after a journalist blabbed its presence to the band's keyboardist?
